review.title: Novelty Learning via Collaborative Proximity Filtering
review.abstract: The vast majority of recommender systems model preferences as static or slowly changing due to observable user experience. However, spontaneous changes in user preferences are ubiquitous in many domains like media consumption and key factors that drive changes in preferences are not directly observable. These latent sources of preference change pose new challenges. When systems do not track and adapt to users' tastes, users lose confidence and trust, increasing the risk of user churn. We meet these challenges by developing a model of novelty preferences that learns and tracks latent user tastes. We combine three innovations: a new measure of item similarity based on patterns of consumption co-occurrence; model for {\em spontaneous} changes in preferences; and a learning agent that tracks each user's dynamic preferences and learns individualized policies for variety. The resulting framework adaptively provides users with novelty tailored to their preferences for change per se.

sections.heading: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: We have evaluated our model on the basis of the last.fm music listening data set and discuss user behaviour, followed by innovations.

sections.heading: User Quit and Novelty Seeking Behavior in Taste Space
sections.text: We look at the exit behavior of users with respect to their taste profile sequences. We calculate an average similarity value of the taste profile by comparing the taste profile of users in the current session with that of the previous session. This measurement is used to demonstrate the ability of our taste model to learn user behavior from two sample users - one who stopped using the services within 449 days and another who continues to use music listening services. Figure 10a shows that the average number of tracks listened to in one month by the "retiring" user continued to decline and the system was unable to respond to this behavior because it had no idea whether the user was seeking novelty or not. As shown in Figure 10b, the average similarity of the taste profile for this "retiring" user is lower than the period during which we identify the "retiring" users. "

sections.heading: Value of Personalization
sections.text: The value of the personalization measure shows how beneficial it is to take into account the personalization of the user. To evaluate it, we look at policies learned for users and apply them to other users besides themselves using an 80-20 validation rate. This means that for a user i we evaluate the policies of the learner against all other users besides i to know how they work if he does not apply his own policies. From this matrix form, the value of the personalization is derived using the definition in Equation 10. As shown in Figure 11, an average total gain for a user applying his own policies is about 8 points. We observe that a user has a lower profit and this is attributed to a globally defined parameter, the duration of sessions, in order to maintain the evaluation consistency between users.

sections.heading: Market Benefit
sections.text: Current referral systems regard users "behavioral preferences as fixed, and it is difficult for computer systems to track non-observable behaviors such as boredom. With the ability to learn such implicit behaviors, our method has enormous potential in a number of areas such as music, movies, etc., which depend heavily on the user's taste and choice.

sections.heading: CONCLUSION
sections.text: Our method fills a fundamental gap in learning implicit user behavior. After an initial phase of interacting with the system, users become bored with stale and repetitive content that does not correspond to their implicit tastes and lose confidence in the system. Therefore, the ability to learn the protracted state of the users is important for the retention and satisfaction of the user. We presented a new method called cooperative proximity filtering by using consumption patterns. The richness in understanding implicit and latent states that the taste model provides is not practicable in the article room. We presented a learning agent that learns novel behavior in the taste room. Proactive knowledge of such user behavior is critical for systems to take action before a user actually cracks and leaves the system. Our method offers a new way to profile users based on their tastes rather than static attributes, so that we should not ignore personalization and that we should be able.
